title: 107_s2449
content: The Act titled "Federal Responsibility for Immigrant Health Act of 2002" allows federal payments under Medicaid for emergency medical conditions of certain aliens. The Act "Federal Responsibility for Immigrant Health Act of 2002" amends Section 1903(v)(2)(A) of the Social Security Act to include necessary care and services for emergency medical conditions, pregnancy-related services, and conditions that may complicate pregnancy for certain aliens under Medicaid. The Act "Federal Responsibility for Immigrant Health Act of 2002" expands Medicaid coverage to include necessary care and services for emergency medical conditions, pregnancy-related services, and conditions that may complicate pregnancy for certain aliens. Additionally, it allows states to eliminate residency requirements for aliens granted parole under section 212(d)(5) of the Social Security Act. The amendments to the Social Security Act allow states to eliminate residency requirements for certain aliens, including those granted parole or admitted as nonimmigrant aliens. The effective date for these changes is upon the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. Funding for emergency health services for undocumented aliens. Funding for emergency health services for undocumented aliens is amended to provide $25,000,000 for fiscal years 1998 through 2001 and $50,000,000 for fiscal years 2003 through 2007. State allotments determination is also amended to include specific guidelines for the Secretary. The State allotments determination under the Balanced Budget Act of 1997 is amended to include specific guidelines for the Secretary to compute allotments for the 15 States with the highest funding for fiscal years 2003 through 2007. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will calculate allotments for the 15 States with the highest percentage of undocumented aliens for fiscal years 2003 through 2007, based on specific guidelines outlined in the Balanced Budget Act of 1997. The amount of allotment to a State is determined based on the percentage of undocumented aliens in the State compared to all States. Any unspent allotment from one fiscal year can be used in the following year. The unspent allotment from one fiscal year can be used in the following year based on the percentage of undocumented aliens in each State. The determination is made using the most recent estimates of the resident illegal alien population. The Statistics Division of the Immigration and Naturalization Service prepares estimates of the alien population in each State. The Balanced Budget Act of 1997 is amended to require funds to assist hospitals and providers of emergency health services to undocumented aliens. The Secretary shall allocate funds to States for hospitals and providers of emergency health services for undocumented aliens in areas with high health costs related to them. The Secretary allocates funds to States for hospitals and providers of emergency health services for undocumented aliens in areas significantly impacted by health costs related to them. The allocation is based on each eligible hospital's payments for emergency medical services under the State plan approved under title XIX of the Social Security Act or an appropriate alternative proxy for measuring the volume of emergency health services provided to undocumented aliens. The Secretary allocates funds to States for hospitals and providers of emergency health services for undocumented aliens based on payments for emergency medical services or an alternative proxy for measuring the volume of services provided. Definitions and special rules apply, including the meaning of 'hospital' and 'provider'. The term 'provider' in section 1861(e) of the Social Security Act includes physicians, health care professionals, and entities providing emergency ambulance services. Providers related to a hospital furnish emergency health services to the same individuals. Amounts paid under this subsection are restricted. The subsection restricts amounts paid for emergency health services provided by hospitals to individuals, ensuring they are not used to replace federal payments to states for emergency medical services. The amendments made by this section apply starting from fiscal year 2003 for the provision of emergency medical services under title XIX of the Act. Allowing states and localities to offer healthcare to all individuals. The Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 is amended to remove certain paragraphs in subsections (b) and (c), including redesignating paragraphs. The Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 is amended to remove certain paragraphs and add a new paragraph stating that health benefits provided by a state or local government are not included in the definition of a specific term. The amendments made by this section are effective immediately. The Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 is amended to exclude health benefits provided by a state or local government from a specific term definition. The amendments apply to health care provided before, on, or after the enactment of the Act.
